Â In short, I argue for a non-anthropocentric yet still phenomenological ethnography of technology, studying not the culture of the people who build and program robots, but the culture of those the robots themselves.

    Technology in the Classroom: A Response to Arthur Bochner

    5 minute read

    An outright ban on technology in the classroom - which may or may not include the pen and paper - is not the right answer. If one wishes to curb disruptive behavior, then ban disruptive behavior instead of banning all the little things that could be disruptive.

    Does Habermas Understand the Internet? The Algorithmic Construction of the Blogo/Public Sphere

    1 minute read

    This is a paper that I recently got published in gnovis, which is a peer-reviewed journal run entirely by graduate students at Georgetownâs Communication, Culture, and Technology program. Â It is a sneakishly Latourian intervention into the debate between Habermasians and post-Habermasians regarding the Internet as a (part of the) public sphere. Â  They have been arguing for some time about whether the Internet (and specifically blogging) leads to political fragmentation or real collective action. Â However, they have all taken for granted the highly-automated software infrastructures that mediate our knowledge of the blogosphere. Â The article is up in HTML on the gnovis site, but Iâve also made a full-text, metadata friendlyÂ PDF simply because Google Scholar likes those. Â  The abstract is after the jump.

    CSCW

    Researching Wikipedia Holistically: A Tentative Approach

    29 minute read

    This is a tentative article-length introduction to my thesis on Wikipedia. It is an attempt to analyze Wikipedia from an interdisciplinary perspective that tries to make problematic various assumptions, concepts, and relations that function quite well in the âreal worldâ but are not well-suited to studying Wikipedia. I begin by talking about the nature of academic disciplines, then proceed to a detailed but sparse review of certain prior research on Wikipedia. By examining the problems in previous research within the context of disciplines, I establish a tentative methodology for a holistic study of Wikipedia.

    Words and Things: A De-Re-Sub-Post-Construction of Rhizomatic and Non-Arborescent Stratum in Deleuze and Guattariâs A Thousand Plateaus

    less than 1 minute read

    This was my final project for an Information Studies class I took back in 2006, when I was an undergraduate at the University of Texas.Â  Our assignment was to transform information from one form to another, and I chose to perform this analysis of Deleuze and Guattariâs A Thousand Plateaus.Â  I scanned and OCRed the entire book and did a visual frequency representation of certain words.Â  I analyzed by chapter and comprehensively with certain core themes in the work.Â  I also did a comprehensive analysis with more general or common words. It is intended to look the way it does, as I am going for a â1960s IBM goes to the academyâ look. Take what you will from it: it is about 35% art, 25% snarky pastiche, 15% pretending to be linguistics, and -5% serious intellectual critique.Â  Here is a sample:

    Ethics

    User-Generated Content as an Ethical Relation

    4 minute read

    I feel bad that I have not written a new entry in so long. I feel like I should apologize - not to the readers, but to the software, to the site itself. I ought to write a new post; I ought to update my status. How did I get into a situation whereby these collections of code could make ethical demands upon me? And is this bad?

    God

    Memetic Inkblots

    7 minute read

    I explore the memetic inkblot, which refers to units of cultural information that have effectively no singular semiotic value and therefore serve as a psychosocial indicator. In other words, they are so vague and open to interpretation that you can learn a lot about someone by asking someone to give a simple definition of them.

    HICSS

    Trace Ethnography: Following Coordination through Documentary Practices

    1 minute read

    This is a paper I co-authored with David Ribes and recently presented at HICSS, the Hawaii International Conference on Systems Sciences. Â Itâs a qualitative methodology based on analyzing logging data that we developed through my research on Wikipedia, but has some pretty broad applications for studying highly-distributed groups. Â Itâs an inversion of the previous paper we presented at CSCW, showing in detail how we traced how Wikipedian vandal fighters as they collectively work to identify and ban malicious contributors.

    Structural Transformation was Habermasâs first of thirty books

    9 minute read

    So given whatâs going on* in Egypt and the Middle East, we in the West are fascinated by not so much revolutions and popular uprisings against dictatorial regimes, but an efficacious use of social media. Even Clinton is talking about the Internet as âthe worldâs town squareâ, and it seems that the old conversation about the Internet and the public sphere is going to flare up for the third time (1993-5 and 2001-3 are the other two times). Since Habermas is generally credited for bringing this notion of the public sphere to the forefront of popular, political, and academic discourse, it is natural to cite him. Â Then critique him to death, talking about how we need to get beyond an old white guyâs theories. Â And it feels good, I know.

    Open Source Software: The Newest Specter?

    15 minute read

    MMORPG

    Notions of Identity Liberation in Virtual Gaming Communities

    18 minute read

    The vast worlds of MMORPGs seem close to postmodern theories of identity, as a player is able to radically constitute their on-line self at will. Despite this, these virtual gaming communities should not be seen as safe spaces in which a subject can realize their true (or ideal) self.

    Response: Me++: The Cyborg Self and the Networked City by William Mitchell

    4 minute read

    In his book Me++: The Cyborg Self and the Networked City, William Mitchell describes how information technology â specifically digital, wireless networks which are accessed primarily through portable devices â fundamentally changes how we interact with others. More than anything else, â[c]onnectivity had become the defining characteristic of our twenty-first-century urban conditionâ (11). For Mitchell, we have given up the virtual reality fantasy that dominated predictions made in previous decades in lieu of subtler revolution: that of the networked self, the Me++.

    Senior Thesis: Democracy in Wikipedia

    1 minute read

    Response: The Structure of Scientific Revolutions by Thomas Kuhn

    7 minute read

    A response to Thomas Kuhnâs The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, in which his work is applied to a personal vignette of experimentation practices in a High School Physics class. When in the course of scientific education should students be allowed to modify scientific theories to fit experimental data instead of modifying experiments to fit the theories?

    academia

    Closed-source papers on open source communities: a problem and a partial solution

    13 minute read

    In the Wikipedia research community â that is, the group of academics and Wikipedians who are interested in studying Wikipedia â there has been a pretty substantial and longstanding problem with how research is published. Academics, from graduate students to tenured faculty, are deeply invested and entrenched in an system that rewards the publication of research. Publish or perish, as weâve all heard. Â  The problem is that the overwhelming majority of publications which are recognized as âacademicâ require us to assign copyright to the publication, so that the publisher can then charge for access to the article. Â This is in direct contradiction with the goals of Wikipedia, as well as many other open source and open content creation communities â communities which are the subject of a substantial amount of academic research.

    Do you support Wikipedia? News from the Trenches of the Science Wars 2.0

    43 minute read

    I show that asking whether Wikipedia is a reliable academic source enframes Wikipedia into an objectless standing-reserve of potential citations, foreclosing many other possibilities for its use. Instead of asking what Wikipedia has done to reality, I ask: what have we done to Wikipedia in the name of reality?

    WebCite: An On-Demand Internet Archive

    1 minute read

    As someone who studies Internet culture, one of my biggest problems is âlink rot,â or broken links.Â  Iâm a big fan of the Internet Archive, but they are usually six to eight months behind on even the most popular sites.Â  I also applaud sites like Wikipedia for providing stable version histories so that I can point to a specific revision of a page.Â  However, for all other websites, the only option is self-archiving, which is technically difficult and fraught with problems.Â  What I have found incredibly useful is WebCite, a free webpage archiving service that fills in this gap.

    algorithms

    A dynamically-generated robots.txt: will search engine bots recognize themselves?

    7 minute read

    In short, I built a script that dynamically generates a robots.txt file for search engine bots, who download the file when they seek direction on what parts of a websiteÂ they are allowed to index. By default, it directs all bots to stay away from the entire site, but then presents an exception: only the bot that requests the robots.txt fileÂ is allowed full reign over the site. If Googleâs bot downloads the robots.txt file, it will see that only Googleâs bot gets to index the entire site. If Yahooâs bot downloads the robots.txt file, it will see that only Yahooâs bot gets to index the entire site. Of course, this is assuming that bots identify themselves to my server in a way that they recognize when it is reflected back to them.

    As someone who studies Internet culture, one of my biggest problems is âlink rot,â or broken links.Â  Iâm a big fan of the Internet Archive, but they are usually six to eight months behind on even the most popular sites.Â  I also applaud sites like Wikipedia for providing stable version histories so that I can point to a specific revision of a page.Â  However, for all other websites, the only option is self-archiving, which is technically difficult and fraught with problems.Â  What I have found incredibly useful is WebCite, a free webpage archiving service that fills in this gap.

    Helvetica: A Documentary, A History, An Anthropology

    13 minute read

    I recently saw Helvetica, a documentary directed by Gary Hustwit about the typeface of the same name â it is available streaming and on DVD from Netflix, for those of you who have a subscription. Â As someone who studies ubiquitous socio-technological infrastructures (and Helvetica is certainly one), I know how hard it is to seriously pay attention to something Â that which we see every day. Â It may seem counter-intuitive, but as Susan Leigh Star reminds us, the more widespread an infrastructure is, the more we use it and depend on it, the more invisible it becomes â that is, until it breaks or generates controversy, in which case it is far too easy. Â But to actually say something about what well-oiled, hidden-in-plain-sight infrastructuresÂ are, how they came to have such a place in our society, and why they won out over their competitors is a notoriously difficult task. Â But I came to realize that the film is less of a history of fonts, and more of an anthropology of design.

    less than 1 minute read

    Does Habermas Understand the Internet? The Algorithmic Construction of the Blogo/Public Sphere

    1 minute read

    This is a paper that I recently got published in gnovis, which is a peer-reviewed journal run entirely by graduate students at Georgetownâs Communication, Culture, and Technology program.     A dynamically-generated robots.txt: will search engine bots recognize themselves?

    7 minute read

    In short, I built a script that dynamically generates a robots.txt file for search engine bots, who download the file when they seek direction on what parts of a websiteÂ they are allowed to index. By default, it directs all bots to stay away from the entire site, but then presents an exception: only the bot that requests the robots.txt fileÂ is allowed full reign over the site. If Googleâs bot downloads the robots.txt file, it will see that only Googleâs bot gets to index the entire site. If Yahooâs bot downloads the robots.txt file, it will see that only Yahooâs bot gets to index the entire site. Of course, this is assuming that bots identify themselves to my server in a way that they recognize when it is reflected back to them.

    Bots, bespoke code, and the materiality of software platforms

    This is a new article published in Information, Communication, and Society as part of their annual special issue for the Association of Internet Researchers (AoIR) conference.     When the Levee Breaks: Without Bots, What Happens to Wikipediaâs Quality Control Processes?

    less than 1 minute read

    Iâve written a number of papers about the role that automated software agents (or bots) play in Wikipedia, claiming that they are critical to the continued operation of Wikipedia. This paper tests this hypothesis and introduces a metric visualizing the speed at which fully-automated bots, tool-assisted cyborgs, and unassisted humans review edits in Wikipedia. In the first half of 2011, ClueBot NG â one of the most prolific counter-vandalism bots in the English-language Wikipedia â went down for four distinct periods, each period of downtime lasting from days to weeks. Aaron Halfaker and I use these periods of breakdown as naturalistic experiments to study Wikipediaâs quality control network. Our analysis showed that the overall time-to-revert damaging edits was almost doubled when this software agent was down. Yet while a significantly fewer proportion of edits made during the botâs downtime were reverted, we found that those edits were later eventually reverted. This suggests that human agents in Wikipedia took over this quality control work, but performed it at a far slower rate.

    About a bot: reflections on building software agents

    less than 1 minute read

    This post for Ethnography Matters is a very personal, reflective musing about the first bot I ever developed for Wikipedia. It makes the argument that while it is certainly important to think about software code and algorithms behind bots and other AI agents, they are not immaterial. In fact, the physical locations and social contexts in which they are run are often critical to understanding how they both âliveâ and âdieâ.

    less than 1 minute read

    Researching Wikipedia Holistically: A Tentative Approach

    29 minute read

    This is a tentative article-length introduction to my thesis on Wikipedia. It is an attempt to analyze Wikipedia from an interdisciplinary perspective that tries to make problematic various assumptions, concepts, and relations that function quite well in the âreal worldâ but are not well-suited to studying Wikipedia. I begin by talking about the nature of academic disciplines, then proceed to a detailed but sparse review of certain prior research on Wikipedia. By examining the problems in previous research within the context of disciplines, I establish a tentative methodology for a holistic study of Wikipedia.

    An apologia for instagram photos of pumpkin spice lattes and other serious things

    13 minute read

    I donât normally pick on people whose work I really admire, but I recently saw a tweet from Mark Sample that struck a nerve: âLook, if you donât instagram your first pumpkin spice latte of the season, humanityâs historical record will be dangerously impoverished.â Â While it got quite a number of retweets and equally snarky responses, he is far from the first to make such a flippant critique of the vapid nature of social media. Â It also seriously upset me for reasons that Iâve been trying to work out, which is why I found myself doing one of those shifts that researchers of knowledge production tend to do far too often with critics: donât get mad, get reflexive. Â What is it that makes such a sentiment resonate with us,Â particularlyÂ when it is issued over Twitter, a platform that is the target of this kind of critique? Â The reasons have to do with a fundamental disagreement over what it means to interact in a mediated space: do we understand our posts, status updates, and shared photos as representations of how we exist in the world which collectively constitute a certain persistent performance of the self, orÂ do we understand them a form of communication in which we subjectively and interactionally relate our experience of the world to others?

    A Communicative Ethnography of Argumentative Strategies in a Wikipedian Content Dispute

    less than 1 minute read

    This presentation was adapted from a chapter in my Senior thesis on Wikipediaâs legal system that focused on a dispute over the inclusion of images of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in an article about him, using a methodology of communicative ethnography. Most who opposed the image were not familiar with Wikipediaâs unique method of content regulation and dispute resolution, as well as its editorial standards and principles. However, most who argued in favor of keeping the image knew these and initially used them to their advantage. This ethnographic study of the communicative strategies used by the parties involved in the dispute shows how new editors to the user-written encyclopedia first emerged in a hostile communicative environment and subsequently adapted their argumentative strategies. This conflict is an excellent example of how disputes are resolved in Wikipedia, showing how this new media space regulates its own content.

    There Is No Cabal: An Investigation into Wikipediaâs Legal Subculture

    16 minute read

    An investigation into the community formed by small number of Wikipedia contributors who care enough to decide how, at some level, Wikipedia is run. The work discusses identity, communication, and organizational hierarchy in this subculture.

    Researching Wikipedia Holistically: A Tentative Approach

    29 minute read

    This is a tentative article-length introduction to my thesis on Wikipedia. It is an attempt to analyze Wikipedia from an interdisciplinary perspective that tries to make problematic various assumptions, concepts, and relations that function quite well in the âreal worldâ but are not well-suited to studying Wikipedia. I begin by talking about the nature of academic disciplines, then proceed to a detailed but sparse review of certain prior research on Wikipedia. By examining the problems in previous research within the context of disciplines, I establish a tentative methodology for a holistic study of Wikipedia.

    A Communicative Ethnography of Argumentative Strategies in a Wikipedian Content Dispute

    less than 1 minute read

    This presentation was adapted from a chapter in my Senior thesis on Wikipediaâs legal system that focused on a dispute over the inclusion of images of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in an article about him, using a methodology of communicative ethnography. Most who opposed the image were not familiar with Wikipediaâs unique method of content regulation and dispute resolution, as well as its editorial standards and principles. However, most who argued in favor of keeping the image knew these and initially used them to their advantage. This ethnographic study of the communicative strategies used by the parties involved in the dispute shows how new editors to the user-written encyclopedia first emerged in a hostile communicative environment and subsequently adapted their argumentative strategies. This conflict is an excellent example of how disputes are resolved in Wikipedia, showing how this new media space regulates its own content.

    An apologia for instagram photos of pumpkin spice lattes and other serious things

    13 minute read

    I donât normally pick on people whose work I really admire, but I recently saw a tweet from Mark Sample that struck a nerve: âLook, if you donât instagram your first pumpkin spice latte of the season, humanityâs historical record will be dangerously impoverished.â Â While it got quite a number of retweets and equally snarky responses, he is far from the first to make such a flippant critique of the vapid nature of social media. Â It also seriously upset me for reasons that Iâve been trying to work out, which is why I found myself doing one of those shifts that researchers of knowledge production tend to do far too often with critics: donât get mad, get reflexive. Â What is it that makes such a sentiment resonate with us,Â particularlyÂ when it is issued over Twitter, a platform that is the target of this kind of critique? Â The reasons have to do with a fundamental disagreement over what it means to interact in a mediated space: do we understand our posts, status updates, and shared photos as representations of how we exist in the world which collectively constitute a certain persistent performance of the self, orÂ do we understand them a form of communication in which we subjectively and interactionally relate our experience of the world to others?

    13 minute read

Â  The problem is that the overwhelming majority of publications which are recognized as âacademicâ require us to assign copyright to the publication, so that the publisher can then charge for access to the article. Â This is in direct contradiction with the goals of Wikipedia, as well as many other open source and open content creation communities â communities which are the subject of a substantial amount of academic research.

    Helvetica: A Documentary, A History, An Anthropology

    13 minute read

    I recently saw Helvetica, a documentary directed by Gary Hustwit about the typeface of the same name â it is available streaming and on DVD from Netflix, for those of you who have a subscription. Â As someone who studies ubiquitous socio-technological infrastructures (and Helvetica is certainly one), I know how hard it is to seriously pay attention to something Â that which we see every day. Â It may seem counter-intuitive, but as Susan Leigh Star reminds us, the more widespread an infrastructure is, the more we use it and depend on it, the more invisible it becomes â that is, until it breaks or generates controversy, in which case it is far too easy. Â But to actually say something about what well-oiled, hidden-in-plain-sight infrastructuresÂ are, how they came to have such a place in our society, and why they won out over their competitors is a notoriously difficult task. Â But I came to realize that the film is less of a history of fonts, and more of an anthropology of design.

    Researching Wikipedia Holistically: A Tentative Approach

    29 minute read

    This is a tentative article-length introduction to my thesis on Wikipedia.     A dynamically-generated robots.txt: will search engine bots recognize themselves?

    7 minute read

    In short, I built a script that dynamically generates a robots.txt file for search engine bots, who download the file when they seek direction on what parts of a websiteÂ they are allowed to index. By default, it directs all bots to stay away from the entire site, but then presents an exception: only the bot that requests the robots.txt fileÂ is allowed full reign over the site. If Googleâs bot downloads the robots.txt file, it will see that only Googleâs bot gets to index the entire site. If Yahooâs bot downloads the robots.txt file, it will see that only Yahooâs bot gets to index the entire site. Of course, this is assuming that bots identify themselves to my server in a way that they recognize when it is reflected back to them.

    An apologia for instagram photos of pumpkin spice lattes and other serious things

    13 minute read

    I donât normally pick on people whose work I really admire, but I recently saw a tweet from Mark Sample that struck a nerve: âLook, if you donât instagram your first pumpkin spice latte of the season, humanityâs historical record will be dangerously impoverished.â Â While it got quite a number of retweets and equally snarky responses, he is far from the first to make such a flippant critique of the vapid nature of social media. Â It also seriously upset me for reasons that Iâve been trying to work out, which is why I found myself doing one of those shifts that researchers of knowledge production tend to do far too often with critics: donât get mad, get reflexive. Â What is it that makes such a sentiment resonate with us,Â particularlyÂ when it is issued over Twitter, a platform that is the target of this kind of critique? Â The reasons have to do with a fundamental disagreement over what it means to interact in a mediated space: do we understand our posts, status updates, and shared photos as representations of how we exist in the world which collectively constitute a certain persistent performance of the self, orÂ do we understand them a form of communication in which we subjectively and interactionally relate our experience of the world to others?

    Does Habermas Understand the Internet? The Algorithmic Construction of the Blogo/Public Sphere

    1 minute read

    This is a paper that I recently got published in gnovis, which is a peer-reviewed journal run entirely by graduate students at Georgetownâs Communication, Culture, and Technology program. Â It is a sneakishly Latourian intervention into the debate between Habermasians and post-Habermasians regarding the Internet as a (part of the) public sphere. Â  They have been arguing for some time about whether the Internet (and specifically blogging) leads to political fragmentation or real collective action. Â However, they have all taken for granted the highly-automated software infrastructures that mediate our knowledge of the blogosphere. Â The article is up in HTML on the gnovis site, but Iâve also made a full-text, metadata friendlyÂ PDF simply because Google Scholar likes those. Â  The abstract is after the jump.

    18 minute read

    dispute resolution

    A Communicative Ethnography of Argumentative Strategies in a Wikipedian Content Dispute

    less than 1 minute read

    This presentation was adapted from a chapter in my Senior thesis on Wikipediaâs legal system that focused on a dispute over the inclusion of images of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in an article about him, using a methodology of communicative ethnography. Most who opposed the image were not familiar with Wikipediaâs unique method of content regulation and dispute resolution, as well as its editorial standards and principles. However, most who argued in favor of keeping the image knew these and initially used them to their advantage. This ethnographic study of the communicative strategies used by the parties involved in the dispute shows how new editors to the user-written encyclopedia first emerged in a hostile communicative environment and subsequently adapted their argumentative strategies. This conflict is an excellent example of how disputes are resolved in Wikipedia, showing how this new media space regulates its own content.

    Closed-source papers on open source communities: a problem and a partial solution

    13 minute read

    In the Wikipedia research community â that is, the group of academics and Wikipedians who are interested in studying Wikipedia â there has been a pretty substantial and longstanding problem with how research is published. Academics, from graduate students to tenured faculty, are deeply invested and entrenched in an system that rewards the publication of research. Publish or perish, as weâve all heard. Â  The problem is that the overwhelming majority of publications which are recognized as âacademicâ require us to assign copyright to the publication, so that the publisher can then charge for access to the article. Â This is in direct contradiction with the goals of Wikipedia, as well as many other open source and open content creation communities â communities which are the subject of a substantial amount of academic research.

    Do you support Wikipedia? News from the Trenches of the Science Wars 2.0

    43 minute read

    I show that asking whether Wikipedia is a reliable academic source enframes Wikipedia into an objectless standing-reserve of potential citations, foreclosing many other possibilities for its use. Instead of asking what Wikipedia has done to reality, I ask: what have we done to Wikipedia in the name of reality?

    User-Generated Content as an Ethical Relation

    4 minute read

    I feel bad that I have not written a new entry in so long. I feel like I should apologize - not to the readers, but to the software, to the site itself. I ought to write a new post; I ought to update my status. How did I get into a situation whereby these collections of code could make ethical demands upon me? And is this bad?

    Helvetica: A Documentary, A History, An Anthropology

    13 minute read

    I recently saw Helvetica, a documentary directed by Gary Hustwit about the typeface of the same name â it is available streaming and on DVD from Netflix, for those of you who have a subscription. Â As someone who studies ubiquitous socio-technological infrastructures (and Helvetica is certainly one), I know how hard it is to seriously pay attention to something Â that which we see every day. Â It may seem counter-intuitive, but as Susan Leigh Star reminds us, the more widespread an infrastructure is, the more we use it and depend on it, the more invisible it becomes â that is, until it breaks or generates controversy, in which case it is far too easy. Â But to actually say something about what well-oiled, hidden-in-plain-sight infrastructuresÂ are, how they came to have such a place in our society, and why they won out over their competitors is a notoriously difficult task. Â But I came to realize that the film is less of a history of fonts, and more of an anthropology of design.

    Wikimania 2008: Flagged Revisions with Philipp Birken

    5 minute read

    From âFlagged Revisions,â a presentation at Wikimania 2008 by Philip Birken. In my opinion, flagged revisions realize the concept of stable versions without making the article actually stable.Â  It is not a system of voting to approve new revisions â a new revision is approved when only one autoconfirmed user says it is vandalism-free.Â  Yes, it wonât solve everything, but it will make things much better.Â  We can get rid of protecting articles that are experiencing heavy vandalism if we do this, because an edit only updates to the public when it is flagged as not-vandalism by a trusted user. However, vandals (or any other user) immediately sees the results of their edit for an hour, which is just ingenious.Â  Also, you can choose whether the most recent revision is shown by default, or make it so that certain users (like anonymous users) only see the most recent reviewed revision.Â  For those who feel that it threatens âthe wiki way,â I suggest making the most recent version appear by default and giving people the option to see the latest reviewed version.

    Memetic Inkblots

    7 minute read

    I explore the memetic inkblot, which refers to units of cultural information that have effectively no singular semiotic value and therefore serve as a psychosocial indicator.     When the Levee Breaks: Without Bots, What Happens to Wikipediaâs Quality Control Processes?

    less than 1 minute read

    Iâve written a number of papers about the role that automated software agents (or bots) play in Wikipedia, claiming that they are critical to the continued operation of Wikipedia. This paper tests this hypothesis and introduces a metric visualizing the speed at which fully-automated bots, tool-assisted cyborgs, and unassisted humans review edits in Wikipedia. In the first half of 2011, ClueBot NG â one of the most prolific counter-vandalism bots in the English-language Wikipedia â went down for four distinct periods, each period of downtime lasting from days to weeks. Aaron Halfaker and I use these periods of breakdown as naturalistic experiments to study Wikipediaâs quality control network. Our analysis showed that the overall time-to-revert damaging edits was almost doubled when this software agent was down. Yet while a significantly fewer proportion of edits made during the botâs downtime were reverted, we found that those edits were later eventually reverted. This suggests that human agents in Wikipedia took over this quality control work, but performed it at a far slower rate.

    Helvetica: A Documentary, A History, An Anthropology

    13 minute read

    I recently saw Helvetica, a documentary directed by Gary Hustwit about the typeface of the same name â it is available streaming and on DVD from Netflix, for those of you who have a subscription. Â As someone who studies ubiquitous socio-technological infrastructures (and Helvetica is certainly one), I know how hard it is to seriously pay attention to something Â that which we see every day. Â It may seem counter-intuitive, but as Susan Leigh Star reminds us, the more widespread an infrastructure is, the more we use it and depend on it, the more invisible it becomes â that is, until it breaks or generates controversy, in which case it is far too easy. Â But to actually say something about what well-oiled, hidden-in-plain-sight infrastructuresÂ are, how they came to have such a place in our society, and why they won out over their competitors is a notoriously difficult task. Â But I came to realize that the film is less of a history of fonts, and more of an anthropology of design.

    less than 1 minute read

    Researching Wikipedia Holistically: A Tentative Approach

    29 minute read

    This is a tentative article-length introduction to my thesis on Wikipedia. It is an attempt to analyze Wikipedia from an interdisciplinary perspective that tries to make problematic various assumptions, concepts, and relations that function quite well in the âreal worldâ but are not well-suited to studying Wikipedia. I begin by talking about the nature of academic disciplines, then proceed to a detailed but sparse review of certain prior research on Wikipedia. By examining the problems in previous research within the context of disciplines, I establish a tentative methodology for a holistic study of Wikipedia.

    7 minute read

    In short, I built a script that dynamically generates a robots.txt file for search engine bots, who download the file when they seek direction on what parts of a websiteÂ they are allowed to index. By default, it directs all bots to stay away from the entire site, but then presents an exception: only the bot that requests the robots.txt fileÂ is allowed full reign over the site. If Googleâs bot downloads the robots.txt file, it will see that only Googleâs bot gets to index the entire site. If Yahooâs bot downloads the robots.txt file, it will see that only Yahooâs bot gets to index the entire site. Of course, this is assuming that bots identify themselves to my server in a way that they recognize when it is reflected back to them.

    When the Levee Breaks: Without Bots, What Happens to Wikipediaâs Quality Control Processes?

    less than 1 minute read

    Iâve written a number of papers about the role that automated software agents (or bots) play in Wikipedia, claiming that they are critical to the continued operation of Wikipedia. This paper tests this hypothesis and introduces a metric visualizing the speed at which fully-automated bots, tool-assisted cyborgs, and unassisted humans review edits in Wikipedia. In the first half of 2011, ClueBot NG â one of the most prolific counter-vandalism bots in the English-language Wikipedia â went down for four distinct periods, each period of downtime lasting from days to weeks. Aaron Halfaker and I use these periods of breakdown as naturalistic experiments to study Wikipediaâs quality control network. Our analysis showed that the overall time-to-revert damaging edits was almost doubled when this software agent was down. Yet while a significantly fewer proportion of edits made during the botâs downtime were reverted, we found that those edits were later eventually reverted. This suggests that human agents in Wikipedia took over this quality control work, but performed it at a far slower rate.

    About a bot: reflections on building software agents

    less than 1 minute read

    This post for Ethnography Matters is a very personal, reflective musing about the first bot I ever developed for Wikipedia. It makes the argument that while it is certainly important to think about software code and algorithms behind bots and other AI agents, they are not immaterial. In fact, the physical locations and social contexts in which they are run are often critical to understanding how they both âliveâ and âdieâ.

    Bots and Cyborgs: Wikipediaâs Immune System

    less than 1 minute read

    My frequent collaborator Aaron Halfaker has written up a fantastic article with John Riedl in ComputerÂ reviewing a lot of the work weâve done on algorithmic agents in Wikipedia, casting them as Wikipediaâs immune system. Choice quote: Â âThese bots and cyborgs are more than tools to better manage content quality on Wikipediaâthrough their interaction with humans, theyâre fundamentally changing its culture.â

    Helvetica: A Documentary, A History, An Anthropology

    13 minute read

    I recently saw Helvetica, a documentary directed by Gary Hustwit about the typeface of the same name â it is available streaming and on DVD from Netflix, for those of you who have a subscription. Â As someone who studies ubiquitous socio-technological infrastructures (and Helvetica is certainly one), I know how hard it is to seriously pay attention to something Â that which we see every day. Â It may seem counter-intuitive, but as Susan Leigh Star reminds us, the more widespread an infrastructure is, the more we use it and depend on it, the more invisible it becomes â that is, until it breaks or generates controversy, in which case it is far too easy. Â But to actually say something about what well-oiled, hidden-in-plain-sight infrastructuresÂ are, how they came to have such a place in our society, and why they won out over their competitors is a notoriously difficult task. Â But I came to realize that the film is less of a history of fonts, and more of an anthropology of design.

    Does Habermas Understand the Internet? The Algorithmic Construction of the Blogo/Public Sphere

    1 minute read

    This is a paper that I recently got published in gnovis, which is a peer-reviewed journal run entirely by graduate students at Georgetownâs Communication, Culture, and Technology program.     Review: Talking About Machines by Julian Orr

    Researching Wikipedia Holistically: A Tentative Approach

    29 minute read

    This is a tentative article-length introduction to my thesis on Wikipedia. It is an attempt to analyze Wikipedia from an interdisciplinary perspective that tries to make problematic various assumptions, concepts, and relations that function quite well in the âreal worldâ but are not well-suited to studying Wikipedia. I begin by talking about the nature of academic disciplines, then proceed to a detailed but sparse review of certain prior research on Wikipedia. By examining the problems in previous research within the context of disciplines, I establish a tentative methodology for a holistic study of Wikipedia.

    Memetic Inkblots

    7 minute read

    I explore the memetic inkblot, which refers to units of cultural information that have effectively no singular semiotic value and therefore serve as a psychosocial indicator. In other words, they are so vague and open to interpretation that you can learn a lot about someone by asking someone to give a simple definition of them.

    An apologia for instagram photos of pumpkin spice lattes and other serious things

    13 minute read

    I donât normally pick on people whose work I really admire, but I recently saw a tweet from Mark Sample that struck a nerve: âLook, if you donât instagram your first pumpkin spice latte of the season, humanityâs historical record will be dangerously impoverished.â Â While it got quite a number of retweets and equally snarky responses, he is far from the first to make such a flippant critique of the vapid nature of social media. Â It also seriously upset me for reasons that Iâve been trying to work out, which is why I found myself doing one of those shifts that researchers of knowledge production tend to do far too often with critics: donât get mad, get reflexive. Â What is it that makes such a sentiment resonate with us,Â particularlyÂ when it is issued over Twitter, a platform that is the target of this kind of critique? Â The reasons have to do with a fundamental disagreement over what it means to interact in a mediated space: do we understand our posts, status updates, and shared photos as representations of how we exist in the world which collectively constitute a certain persistent performance of the self, orÂ do we understand them a form of communication in which we subjectively and interactionally relate our experience of the world to others?

    Closed-source papers on open source communities: a problem and a partial solution

    13 minute read

    In the Wikipedia research community â that is, the group of academics and Wikipedians who are interested in studying Wikipedia â there has been a pretty substantial and longstanding problem with how research is published. Academics, from graduate students to tenured faculty, are deeply invested and entrenched in an system that rewards the publication of research. Publish or perish, as weâve all heard. Â  The problem is that the overwhelming majority of publications which are recognized as âacademicâ require us to assign copyright to the publication, so that the publisher can then charge for access to the article. Â This is in direct contradiction with the goals of Wikipedia, as well as many other open source and open content creation communities â communities which are the subject of a substantial amount of academic research.

    Why arenât the GPL and the GFDL freely licensed?

    4 minute read

    Works licensed under the GPL and the GFDL can be modified and then freely redistributed, as long as the modified versions are released under the same conditions. Why are we not allowed to modify these licenses and redistribute them?

    A Communicative Ethnography of Argumentative Strategies in a Wikipedian Content Dispute

    less than 1 minute read

    This presentation was adapted from a chapter in my Senior thesis on Wikipediaâs legal system that focused on a dispute over the inclusion of images of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in an article about him, using a methodology of communicative ethnography. Most who opposed the image were not familiar with Wikipediaâs unique method of content regulation and dispute resolution, as well as its editorial standards and principles. However, most who argued in favor of keeping the image knew these and initially used them to their advantage. This ethnographic study of the communicative strategies used by the parties involved in the dispute shows how new editors to the user-written encyclopedia first emerged in a hostile communicative environment and subsequently adapted their argumentative strategies. This conflict is an excellent example of how disputes are resolved in Wikipedia, showing how this new media space regulates its own content.

    Does Habermas Understand the Internet? The Algorithmic Construction of the Blogo/Public Sphere

    1 minute read

    This is a paper that I recently got published in gnovis, which is a peer-reviewed journal run entirely by graduate students at Georgetownâs Communication, Culture, and Technology program. Â It is a sneakishly Latourian intervention into the debate between Habermasians and post-Habermasians regarding the Internet as a (part of the) public sphere. Â  They have been arguing for some time about whether the Internet (and specifically blogging) leads to political fragmentation or real collective action. Â However, they have all taken for granted the highly-automated software infrastructures that mediate our knowledge of the blogosphere. Â The article is up in HTML on the gnovis site, but Iâve also made a full-text, metadata friendlyÂ PDF simply because Google Scholar likes those. Â  The abstract is after the jump.

    43 minute read

    4 minute read

    There Is No Cabal: An Investigation into Wikipediaâs Legal Subculture

    16 minute read

    An investigation into the community formed by small number of Wikipedia contributors who care enough to decide how, at some level, Wikipedia is run. The work discusses identity, communication, and organizational hierarchy in this subculture.

    Senior Thesis: Democracy in Wikipedia

    1 minute read

    My thesis studied the legal culture of Wikipedia to examine the law through stories and histories, giving the reader a sense of not only what the Wikipedian legal system is, but also what fundamental assumptions the community makes in utilizing such a system.

    Notions of Identity Liberation in Virtual Gaming Communities

    18 minute read

    The vast worlds of MMORPGs seem close to postmodern theories of identity, as a player is able to radically constitute their on-line self at will. Despite this, these virtual gaming communities should not be seen as safe spaces in which a subject can realize their true (or ideal) self.

    15 minute read

    Corporate adoption of open source software should not be viewed as antithetical to capitalism; rather, it is an example of corporations co-opting Communism to become more capitalist.

    Memetic Inkblots

    7 minute read

    I explore the memetic inkblot, which refers to units of cultural information that have effectively no singular semiotic value and therefore serve as a psychosocial indicator. In other words, they are so vague and open to interpretation that you can learn a lot about someone by asking someone to give a simple definition of them.

    less than 1 minute read

    This was my final project for an Information Studies class I took back in 2006, when I was an undergraduate at the University of Texas.Â  Our assignment was to transform information from one form to another, and I chose to perform this analysis of Deleuze and Guattariâs A Thousand Plateaus.Â  I scanned and OCRed the entire book and did a visual frequency representation of certain words.Â  I analyzed by chapter and comprehensively with certain core themes in the work.Â  I also did a comprehensive analysis with more general or common words. It is intended to look the way it does, as I am going for a â1960s IBM goes to the academyâ look. Take what you will from it: it is about 35% art, 25% snarky pastiche, 15% pretending to be linguistics, and -5% serious intellectual critique.Â  Here is a sample:

    Helvetica: A Documentary, A History, An Anthropology

    13 minute read

    I recently saw Helvetica, a documentary directed by Gary Hustwit about the typeface of the same name â it is available streaming and on DVD from Netflix, for those of you who have a subscription. Â As someone who studies ubiquitous socio-technological infrastructures (and Helvetica is certainly one), I know how hard it is to seriously pay attention to something Â that which we see every day. Â It may seem counter-intuitive, but as Susan Leigh Star reminds us, the more widespread an infrastructure is, the more we use it and depend on it, the more invisible it becomes â that is, until it breaks or generates controversy, in which case it is far too easy. Â But to actually say something about what well-oiled, hidden-in-plain-sight infrastructuresÂ are, how they came to have such a place in our society, and why they won out over their competitors is a notoriously difficult task. Â But I came to realize that the film is less of a history of fonts, and more of an anthropology of design.

    About a bot: reflections on building software agents

    less than 1 minute read

    This post for Ethnography Matters is a very personal, reflective musing about the first bot I ever developed for Wikipedia.     WebCite: An On-Demand Internet Archive

    1 minute read

    As someone who studies Internet culture, one of my biggest problems is âlink rot,â or broken links.Â  Iâm a big fan of the Internet Archive, but they are usually six to eight months behind on even the most popular sites.Â  I also applaud sites like Wikipedia for providing stable version histories so that I can point to a specific revision of a page.Â  However, for all other websites, the only option is self-archiving, which is technically difficult and fraught with problems.Â  What I have found incredibly useful is WebCite, a free webpage archiving service that fills in this gap.

    Researching Wikipedia Holistically: A Tentative Approach

    29 minute read

    This is a tentative article-length introduction to my thesis on Wikipedia. It is an attempt to analyze Wikipedia from an interdisciplinary perspective that tries to make problematic various assumptions, concepts, and relations that function quite well in the âreal worldâ but are not well-suited to studying Wikipedia. I begin by talking about the nature of academic disciplines, then proceed to a detailed but sparse review of certain prior research on Wikipedia. By examining the problems in previous research within the context of disciplines, I establish a tentative methodology for a holistic study of Wikipedia.

    The Facticity of Art

    less than 1 minute read

    This is a piece of web art or net art, with an included work of art criticism about the piece. The work makes the argument that while interactive digital art can be considered user-centered, this new style and medium is only centered around those possibilities that the creator wishes to make available to the user. You can see The Facticity of Art at http://stuartgeiger.com/art/art-intro.shtml.

    Does Habermas Understand the Internet? The Algorithmic Construction of the Blogo/Public Sphere

    1 minute read

    This is a paper that I recently got published in gnovis, which is a peer-reviewed journal run entirely by graduate students at Georgetownâs Communication, Culture, and Technology program. Â It is a sneakishly Latourian intervention into the debate between Habermasians and post-Habermasians regarding the Internet as a (part of the) public sphere. Â  They have been arguing for some time about whether the Internet (and specifically blogging) leads to political fragmentation or real collective action. Â However, they have all taken for granted the highly-automated software infrastructures that mediate our knowledge of the blogosphere. Â The article is up in HTML on the gnovis site, but Iâve also made a full-text, metadata friendlyÂ PDF simply because Google Scholar likes those. Â  The abstract is after the jump.

    User-Generated Content as an Ethical Relation

    4 minute read

    I feel bad that I have not written a new entry in so long. I feel like I should apologize - not to the readers, but to the software, to the site itself. I ought to write a new post; I ought to update my status. How did I get into a situation whereby these collections of code could make ethical demands upon me? And is this bad?

    Closed-source papers on open source communities: a problem and a partial solution

    13 minute read

    In the Wikipedia research community â that is, the group of academics and Wikipedians who are interested in studying Wikipedia â there has been a pretty substantial and longstanding problem with how research is published. Academics, from graduate students to tenured faculty, are deeply invested and entrenched in an system that rewards the publication of research. Publish or perish, as weâve all heard. Â  The problem is that the overwhelming majority of publications which are recognized as âacademicâ require us to assign copyright to the publication, so that the publisher can then charge for access to the article. Â This is in direct contradiction with the goals of Wikipedia, as well as many other open source and open content creation communities â communities which are the subject of a substantial amount of academic research.

    Memetic Inkblots

    7 minute read

    I explore the memetic inkblot, which refers to units of cultural information that have effectively no singular semiotic value and therefore serve as a psychosocial indicator. In other words, they are so vague and open to interpretation that you can learn a lot about someone by asking someone to give a simple definition of them.

    Why arenât the GPL and the GFDL freely licensed?

    4 minute read

    Works licensed under the GPL and the GFDL can be modified and then freely redistributed, as long as the modified versions are released under the same conditions. Why are we not allowed to modify these licenses and redistribute them?

    There Is No Cabal: An Investigation into Wikipediaâs Legal Subculture

    16 minute read

    An investigation into the community formed by small number of Wikipedia contributors who care enough to decide how, at some level, Wikipedia is run. The work discusses identity, communication, and organizational hierarchy in this subculture.

    15 minute read

    Corporate adoption of open source software should not be viewed as antithetical to capitalism; rather, it is an example of corporations co-opting Communism to become more capitalist.

    1 minute read

Â Itâs an inversion of the previous paper we presented at CSCW, showing in detail how we traced how Wikipedian vandal fighters as they collectively work to identify and ban malicious contributors.

    A dynamically-generated robots.txt: will search engine bots recognize themselves?

    7 minute read

    In short, I built a script that dynamically generates a robots.txt file for search engine bots, who download the file when they seek direction on what parts of a websiteÂ they are allowed to index. By default, it directs all bots to stay away from the entire site, but then presents an exception: only the bot that requests the robots.txt fileÂ is allowed full reign over the site. If Googleâs bot downloads the robots.txt file, it will see that only Googleâs bot gets to index the entire site. If Yahooâs bot downloads the robots.txt file, it will see that only Yahooâs bot gets to index the entire site. Of course, this is assuming that bots identify themselves to my server in a way that they recognize when it is reflected back to them.

    About a bot: reflections on building software agents

    less than 1 minute read

    This post for Ethnography Matters is a very personal, reflective musing about the first bot I ever developed for Wikipedia. It makes the argument that while it is certainly important to think about software code and algorithms behind bots and other AI agents, they are not immaterial. In fact, the physical locations and social contexts in which they are run are often critical to understanding how they both âliveâ and âdieâ.

    4 minute read

    An apologia for instagram photos of pumpkin spice lattes and other serious things

    13 minute read

    I donât normally pick on people whose work I really admire, but I recently saw a tweet from Mark Sample that struck a nerve: âLook, if you donât instagram your first pumpkin spice latte of the season, humanityâs historical record will be dangerously impoverished.â Â While it got quite a number of retweets and equally snarky responses, he is far from the first to make such a flippant critique of the vapid nature of social media. Â It also seriously upset me for reasons that Iâve been trying to work out, which is why I found myself doing one of those shifts that researchers of knowledge production tend to do far too often with critics: donât get mad, get reflexive. Â What is it that makes such a sentiment resonate with us,Â particularlyÂ when it is issued over Twitter, a platform that is the target of this kind of critique? Â The reasons have to do with a fundamental disagreement over what it means to interact in a mediated space: do we understand our posts, status updates, and shared photos as representations of how we exist in the world which collectively constitute a certain persistent performance of the self, orÂ do we understand them a form of communication in which we subjectively and interactionally relate our experience of the world to others?

    Researching Wikipedia Holistically: A Tentative Approach

    29 minute read

    This is a tentative article-length introduction to my thesis on Wikipedia. It is an attempt to analyze Wikipedia from an interdisciplinary perspective that tries to make problematic various assumptions, concepts, and relations that function quite well in the âreal worldâ but are not well-suited to studying Wikipedia. I begin by talking about the nature of academic disciplines, then proceed to a detailed but sparse review of certain prior research on Wikipedia. By examining the problems in previous research within the context of disciplines, I establish a tentative methodology for a holistic study of Wikipedia.

    Wikimania 2008: Flagged Revisions with Philipp Birken

    5 minute read

    From âFlagged Revisions,â a presentation at Wikimania 2008 by Philip Birken. In my opinion, flagged revisions realize the concept of stable versions without making the article actually stable.Â  It is not a system of voting to approve new revisions â a new revision is approved when only one autoconfirmed user says it is vandalism-free.Â  Yes, it wonât solve everything, but it will make things much better.Â  We can get rid of protecting articles that are experiencing heavy vandalism if we do this, because an edit only updates to the public when it is flagged as not-vandalism by a trusted user. However, vandals (or any other user) immediately sees the results of their edit for an hour, which is just ingenious.Â  Also, you can choose whether the most recent revision is shown by default, or make it so that certain users (like anonymous users) only see the most recent reviewed revision.Â  For those who feel that it threatens âthe wiki way,â I suggest making the most recent version appear by default and giving people the option to see the latest reviewed version.

    11 minute read

    Have you done historical bibliometric analysis of a scientific field or topic area and found that there is a massive increase in research articles after 1990?Â  Are you using ISIâs Web of Science and searching by topic or keyword?Â  If so, donât make the same mistake I did: these results arenât because of some sea change or paradigm shift, but rather result from a poorly-documented shift in how ISI began indexing articles after 1990.

    When the Levee Breaks: Without Bots, What Happens to Wikipediaâs Quality Control Processes?

    less than 1 minute read

    Iâve written a number of papers about the role that automated software agents (or bots) play in Wikipedia, claiming that they are critical to the continued operation of Wikipedia. This paper tests this hypothesis and introduces a metric visualizing the speed at which fully-automated bots, tool-assisted cyborgs, and unassisted humans review edits in Wikipedia. In the first half of 2011, ClueBot NG â one of the most prolific counter-vandalism bots in the English-language Wikipedia â went down for four distinct periods, each period of downtime lasting from days to weeks. Aaron Halfaker and I use these periods of breakdown as naturalistic experiments to study Wikipediaâs quality control network. Our analysis showed that the overall time-to-revert damaging edits was almost doubled when this software agent was down. Yet while a significantly fewer proportion of edits made during the botâs downtime were reverted, we found that those edits were later eventually reverted. This suggests that human agents in Wikipedia took over this quality control work, but performed it at a far slower rate.

    Closed-source papers on open source communities: a problem and a partial solution

    13 minute read

    In the Wikipedia research community â that is, the group of academics and Wikipedians who are interested in studying Wikipedia â there has been a pretty substantial and longstanding problem with how research is published. Â  The problem is that the overwhelming majority of publications which are recognized as âacademicâ require us to assign copyright to the publication, so that the publisher can then charge for access to the article. Â This is in direct contradiction with the goals of Wikipedia, as well as many other open source and open content creation communities â communities which are the subject of a substantial amount of academic research.

    Memetic Inkblots

    7 minute read

    I explore the memetic inkblot, which refers to units of cultural information that have effectively no singular semiotic value and therefore serve as a psychosocial indicator. In other words, they are so vague and open to interpretation that you can learn a lot about someone by asking someone to give a simple definition of them.

    An apologia for instagram photos of pumpkin spice lattes and other serious things

    13 minute read

    I donât normally pick on people whose work I really admire, but I recently saw a tweet from Mark Sample that struck a nerve: âLook, if you donât instagram your first pumpkin spice latte of the season, humanityâs historical record will be dangerously impoverished.â Â While it got quite a number of retweets and equally snarky responses, he is far from the first to make such a flippant critique of the vapid nature of social media. Â It also seriously upset me for reasons that Iâve been trying to work out, which is why I found myself doing one of those shifts that researchers of knowledge production tend to do far too often with critics: donât get mad, get reflexive. Â What is it that makes such a sentiment resonate with us,Â particularlyÂ when it is issued over Twitter, a platform that is the target of this kind of critique? Â The reasons have to do with a fundamental disagreement over what it means to interact in a mediated space: do we understand our posts, status updates, and shared photos as representations of how we exist in the world which collectively constitute a certain persistent performance of the self, orÂ do we understand them a form of communication in which we subjectively and interactionally relate our experience of the world to others?

    Wikimania 2008: Flagged Revisions with Philipp Birken

    5 minute read

    From âFlagged Revisions,â a presentation at Wikimania 2008 by Philip Birken. In my opinion, flagged revisions realize the concept of stable versions without making the article actually stable.Â  It is not a system of voting to approve new revisions â a new revision is approved when only one autoconfirmed user says it is vandalism-free.Â  Yes, it wonât solve everything, but it will make things much better.Â  We can get rid of protecting articles that are experiencing heavy vandalism if we do this, because an edit only updates to the public when it is flagged as not-vandalism by a trusted user. However, vandals (or any other user) immediately sees the results of their edit for an hour, which is just ingenious.Â  Also, you can choose whether the most recent revision is shown by default, or make it so that certain users (like anonymous users) only see the most recent reviewed revision.Â  For those who feel that it threatens âthe wiki way,â I suggest making the most recent version appear by default and giving people the option to see the latest reviewed version.

Â It is a sneakishly Latourian intervention into the debate between Habermasians and post-Habermasians regarding the Internet as a (part of the) public sphere. Â  They have been arguing for some time about whether the Internet (and specifically blogging) leads to political fragmentation or real collective action. Â However, they have all taken for granted the highly-automated software infrastructures that mediate our knowledge of the blogosphere.     A dynamically-generated robots.txt: will search engine bots recognize themselves?

    7 minute read

    In short, I built a script that dynamically generates a robots.txt file for search engine bots, who download the file when they seek direction on what parts of a websiteÂ they are allowed to index. By default, it directs all bots to stay away from the entire site, but then presents an exception: only the bot that requests the robots.txt fileÂ is allowed full reign over the site. If Googleâs bot downloads the robots.txt file, it will see that only Googleâs bot gets to index the entire site. If Yahooâs bot downloads the robots.txt file, it will see that only Yahooâs bot gets to index the entire site. Of course, this is assuming that bots identify themselves to my server in a way that they recognize when it is reflected back to them.

    Bots, bespoke code, and the materiality of software platforms

    When the Levee Breaks: Without Bots, What Happens to Wikipediaâs Quality Control Processes?

    less than 1 minute read

    Iâve written a number of papers about the role that automated software agents (or bots) play in Wikipedia, claiming that they are critical to the continued operation of Wikipedia. This paper tests this hypothesis and introduces a metric visualizing the speed at which fully-automated bots, tool-assisted cyborgs, and unassisted humans review edits in Wikipedia. In the first half of 2011, ClueBot NG â one of the most prolific counter-vandalism bots in the English-language Wikipedia â went down for four distinct periods, each period of downtime lasting from days to weeks. Aaron Halfaker and I use these periods of breakdown as naturalistic experiments to study Wikipediaâs quality control network. Our analysis showed that the overall time-to-revert damaging edits was almost doubled when this software agent was down. Yet while a significantly fewer proportion of edits made during the botâs downtime were reverted, we found that those edits were later eventually reverted. This suggests that human agents in Wikipedia took over this quality control work, but performed it at a far slower rate.

    About a bot: reflections on building software agents

    less than 1 minute read

    This post for Ethnography Matters is a very personal, reflective musing about the first bot I ever developed for Wikipedia. It makes the argument that while it is certainly important to think about software code and algorithms behind bots and other AI agents, they are not immaterial. In fact, the physical locations and social contexts in which they are run are often critical to understanding how they both âliveâ and âdieâ.

    This was an interview I did with the wonderfulÂ Heather Ford,Â originally posted at Ethnography Matters (a really cool group blog) way back in January. Â In short, I argue for a non-anthropocentric yet still phenomenological ethnography of technology, studying not the culture of the people who build and program robots, but the culture of those the robots themselves.

    Helvetica: A Documentary, A History, An Anthropology

    13 minute read

    I recently saw Helvetica, a documentary directed by Gary Hustwit about the typeface of the same name â it is available streaming and on DVD from Netflix, for those of you who have a subscription. Â As someone who studies ubiquitous socio-technological infrastructures (and Helvetica is certainly one), I know how hard it is to seriously pay attention to something Â that which we see every day. Â It may seem counter-intuitive, but as Susan Leigh Star reminds us, the more widespread an infrastructure is, the more we use it and depend on it, the more invisible it becomes â that is, until it breaks or generates controversy, in which case it is far too easy. Â But to actually say something about what well-oiled, hidden-in-plain-sight infrastructuresÂ are, how they came to have such a place in our society, and why they won out over their competitors is a notoriously difficult task. Â But I came to realize that the film is less of a history of fonts, and more of an anthropology of design.

    An apologia for instagram photos of pumpkin spice lattes and other serious things

    13 minute read

    I donât normally pick on people whose work I really admire, but I recently saw a tweet from Mark Sample that struck a nerve: âLook, if you donât instagram your first pumpkin spice latte of the season, humanityâs historical record will be dangerously impoverished.â Â While it got quite a number of retweets and equally snarky responses, he is far from the first to make such a flippant critique of the vapid nature of social media. Â It also seriously upset me for reasons that Iâve been trying to work out, which is why I found myself doing one of those shifts that researchers of knowledge production tend to do far too often with critics: donât get mad, get reflexive. Â What is it that makes such a sentiment resonate with us,Â particularlyÂ when it is issued over Twitter, a platform that is the target of this kind of critique? Â The reasons have to do with a fundamental disagreement over what it means to interact in a mediated space: do we understand our posts, status updates, and shared photos as representations of how we exist in the world which collectively constitute a certain persistent performance of the self, orÂ do we understand them a form of communication in which we subjectively and interactionally relate our experience of the world to others?

    Wikimania 2008: Flagged Revisions with Philipp Birken

    5 minute read

    From âFlagged Revisions,â a presentation at Wikimania 2008 by Philip Birken. In my opinion, flagged revisions realize the concept of stable versions without making the article actually stable.Â  It is not a system of voting to approve new revisions â a new revision is approved when only one autoconfirmed user says it is vandalism-free.Â  Yes, it wonât solve everything, but it will make things much better.Â  We can get rid of protecting articles that are experiencing heavy vandalism if we do this, because an edit only updates to the public when it is flagged as not-vandalism by a trusted user. However, vandals (or any other user) immediately sees the results of their edit for an hour, which is just ingenious.Â  Also, you can choose whether the most recent revision is shown by default, or make it so that certain users (like anonymous users) only see the most recent reviewed revision.Â  For those who feel that it threatens âthe wiki way,â I suggest making the most recent version appear by default and giving people the option to see the latest reviewed version.

    Memetic Inkblots

    7 minute read

    I explore the memetic inkblot, which refers to units of cultural information that have effectively no singular semiotic value and therefore serve as a psychosocial indicator. In other words, they are so vague and open to interpretation that you can learn a lot about someone by asking someone to give a simple definition of them.

    The Facticity of Art

    less than 1 minute read

    This is a piece of web art or net art, with an included work of art criticism about the piece. The work makes the argument that while interactive digital art can be considered user-centered, this new style and medium is only centered around those possibilities that the creator wishes to make available to the user. You can see The Facticity of Art at http://stuartgeiger.com/art/art-intro.shtml.

    Perils of Keyword-Based Bibliometrics: ISIâs â1990 Effectâ

    11 minute read

    A Communicative Ethnography of Argumentative Strategies in a Wikipedian Content Dispute

    less than 1 minute read

    This presentation was adapted from a chapter in my Senior thesis on Wikipediaâs legal system that focused on a dispute over the inclusion of images of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in an article about him, using a methodology of communicative ethnography. Most who opposed the image were not familiar with Wikipediaâs unique method of content regulation and dispute resolution, as well as its editorial standards and principles. However, most who argued in favor of keeping the image knew these and initially used them to their advantage. This ethnographic study of the communicative strategies used by the parties involved in the dispute shows how new editors to the user-written encyclopedia first emerged in a hostile communicative environment and subsequently adapted their argumentative strategies. This conflict is an excellent example of how disputes are resolved in Wikipedia, showing how this new media space regulates its own content.

    1 minute read

    Wikimania 2008: Flagged Revisions with Philipp Birken

    5 minute read

    From âFlagged Revisions,â a presentation at Wikimania 2008 by Philip Birken. In my opinion, flagged revisions realize the concept of stable versions without making the article actually stable.Â  It is not a system of voting to approve new revisions â a new revision is approved when only one autoconfirmed user says it is vandalism-free.Â  Yes, it wonât solve everything, but it will make things much better.Â  We can get rid of protecting articles that are experiencing heavy vandalism if we do this, because an edit only updates to the public when it is flagged as not-vandalism by a trusted user. However, vandals (or any other user) immediately sees the results of their edit for an hour, which is just ingenious.Â  Also, you can choose whether the most recent revision is shown by default, or make it so that certain users (like anonymous users) only see the most recent reviewed revision.Â  For those who feel that it threatens âthe wiki way,â I suggest making the most recent version appear by default and giving people the option to see the latest reviewed version.

    Conceptions and Misconceptions Academics Hold About Wikipedia

    4 minute read

    As an ethnographer, I enter into communities, learn their customs, beliefs, and practices, then report back to the academy to share what I have discovered. In this presentation, I wish to do the opposite, presenting to the Wikipedian community an ethnography of academics as they relate to Wikipedia.

    Closed-source papers on open source communities: a problem and a partial solution

    13 minute read

    In the Wikipedia research community â that is, the group of academics and Wikipedians who are interested in studying Wikipedia â there has been a pretty substantial and longstanding problem with how research is published. Academics, from graduate students to tenured faculty, are deeply invested and entrenched in an system that rewards the publication of research. Publish or perish, as weâve all heard. Â  The problem is that the overwhelming majority of publications which are recognized as âacademicâ require us to assign copyright to the publication, so that the publisher can then charge for access to the article. Â This is in direct contradiction with the goals of Wikipedia, as well as many other open source and open content creation communities â communities which are the subject of a substantial amount of academic research.

    Bots, bespoke code, and the materiality of software platforms

    1 minute read

    This is a new article published in Information, Communication, and Society as part of their annual special issue for the Association of Internet Researchers (AoIR) conference. This yearâs special issue was edited by Lee Humphreys and Tarleton Gillespie, who did a great job throughout the whole process.

    When the Levee Breaks: Without Bots, What Happens to Wikipediaâs Quality Control Processes?

    less than 1 minute read

    Iâve written a number of papers about the role that automated software agents (or bots) play in Wikipedia, claiming that they are critical to the continued operation of Wikipedia. This paper tests this hypothesis and introduces a metric visualizing the speed at which fully-automated bots, tool-assisted cyborgs, and unassisted humans review edits in Wikipedia. In the first half of 2011, ClueBot NG â one of the most prolific counter-vandalism bots in the English-language Wikipedia â went down for four distinct periods, each period of downtime lasting from days to weeks. Aaron Halfaker and I use these periods of breakdown as naturalistic experiments to study Wikipediaâs quality control network. Our analysis showed that the overall time-to-revert damaging edits was almost doubled when this software agent was down. Yet while a significantly fewer proportion of edits made during the botâs downtime were reverted, we found that those edits were later eventually reverted. This suggests that human agents in Wikipedia took over this quality control work, but performed it at a far slower rate.

    About a bot: reflections on building software agents

    less than 1 minute read

    This post for Ethnography Matters is a very personal, reflective musing about the first bot I ever developed for Wikipedia. It makes the argument that while it is certainly important to think about software code and algorithms behind bots and other AI agents, they are not immaterial. In fact, the physical locations and social contexts in which they are run are often critical to understanding how they both âliveâ and âdieâ.

    Bots and Cyborgs: Wikipediaâs Immune System

    less than 1 minute read

    My frequent collaborator Aaron Halfaker has written up a fantastic article with John Riedl in ComputerÂ reviewing a lot of the work weâve done on algorithmic agents in Wikipedia, casting them as Wikipediaâs immune system. Choice quote: Â âThese bots and cyborgs are more than tools to better manage content quality on Wikipediaâthrough their interaction with humans, theyâre fundamentally changing its culture.â

    Trace Ethnography: Following Coordination through Documentary Practices

    1 minute read

    This is a paper I co-authored with David Ribes and recently presented at HICSS, the Hawaii International Conference on Systems Sciences. Â Itâs a qualitative methodology based on analyzing logging data that we developed through my research on Wikipedia, but has some pretty broad applications for studying highly-distributed groups. Â Itâs an inversion of the previous paper we presented at CSCW, showing in detail how we traced how Wikipedian vandal fighters as they collectively work to identify and ban malicious contributors.

    Evolving Governance and Media Use in Wikipedia: A Historical Account

    3 minute read
